yes but if you have a different Ubuntu version there I still don't recommend it
, 2 same machines, both ubuntu 8.04
well, basically the first question you should ask you is: have I touched any file in /etc?
if the answer is not, then you don't need them. if the answer is yes, try to remember what files it where and copy them, or duplicate the changes you did
ok , think i got the idea:) tnx
the really important stuff are the hidden files from your home directory, which contain the configuration and data (when applicable) of all your applications
yw
what about replicating all software from one machien to other? that is all hidden in /etc, right ?
installing the same applications you mean? no, they are all around the filesystem (binaries in /bin, /sbin/, /usr/bin or /usr/games, data in /usr/share/, global configuration in /etc, etc.)
you can get a list of all installed packages and install them on the new PC if you wnat, though
(if you're interested I can tell you what the command for that would be)
also, if you don't want to download the packages again many of them should still be /var/cache/apt/archive; you can copy the files from there over to the other machine
one moment..
so copy files from main machine /var/cache/apt/archive to 2nd machine , then install programs u mean ?*
yes. I'm trying to think of a command to get a list of all installed programs, will tell you in a moment
ok tnx
dpkg -l | cut -d' ' -f3 | grep -v '=' | grep -v '(' | xargs echo > filelist
